questions.text: Which of the following is most common type of emphysema?
questions.solution:
A. Centiacinar or centrilobular is the most common form, constituting more than 95% of clinically significant cases.

The four main types of emphysema are:


  • Centriacinar: The most common type, which usually occurs in the upper lungs and is associated with smoking
  • Panacinar: Usually occurs in the lower lungs and is associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
  • Paraseptal: Usually occurs around the septa or pleura and is associated with inflammatory processes, such as lung infections
  • Para cicatricial: Also known as irregular emphysema, this type is associated with fibrosis

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER: 679.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a 2-month history of dry cough, shortness of breath, and fatigue. She also notices painful red nodules on her legs. On physical examination, she has bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and lung crackles. Her angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) levels are high. Histopatological findings shown in figures. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sarcoidosis is of multisystem disease of unknown etiology.

  • It is worldwide in distribution and affects adults from 20-40 years of age.
  • The combination of respiratory symptoms, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, skin lesions (erythema nodosum), elevated ACE levels and histopathological images which are of asteroid bodiesand non caseating granulomas are characteristic of sarcoidosis.

REFERENCE: HARSHMOHAN textbook of pathology, 7TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER: 154, 155.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents with Coughing up blood, Chest pain and Weight loss. Imaging studies reveal:

1. 2 cm mass in the left lower lobe
2. No hilar lymphadenopathy
3. No distant metastases

Biopsy of the mass reveals:
1. Malignant cells with clear cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli
2. Cells are arranged in a papillary pattern
3. Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for CK7 and TTF-1

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A. patient's symptoms and imaging findings, combined with the biopsy results, are consistent with adenocarcinoma.

  • The clear cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli are characteristic of adenocarcinoma cells.
  • The papillary pattern of the cells is also typical of adenocarcinoma.
  • The positivity for CK7 and TTF-1 on immunohistochemistry confirms the diagnosis, as these markers are commonly expressed in adenocarcinoma.

B. The presence of keratinizationand intercellular bridges is a hallmark of squamous cell carcinoma.

  • CK5/6 and p63 on immunohistochemistry markers are commonly expressed in squamous cell carcinoma.

C. The biopsy findings of small, round nuclei and scant cytoplasm, arranged in a sheet-like pattern with nuclear molding, are characteristic of small cell carcinoma.

  • The positivity for CD56, synaptophysin, and TTF-1 on immunohistochemistry markers are commonly expressed in small cell carcinoma.

D. Bronchoalveolar carcinoma (BAC) is characterized by:

  • Glandular or lepidic growth along alveolar septa
  • Cuboidal or columnar cells with mucinous or non-mucinous features
  • Preserved lung architecture
  • Absence of stromal invasion

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER: 718.

choices.text: Dense core neurosecretory granules on electron microscopy

questions.text: Lung Biopsy of 60 year old patient with chest pain and weight loss, reveals Azzopardi effect with high mitotic rate and necrosis. Which is true statement about this condition?
questions.solution:
• Azzopardi effect, high mitotic rate, and necrosis are characteristic feature of small cell carcinoma of the lung.
  • Dense core neurosecretory granules on electron microscopy (Option c) (DCNSGs) are a characteristic feature of neuroendocrine tumors, including small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) and other lung neuroendocrine tumors.

DCNSGs are:

  1. Membrane-bound granules
  2. Electron-dense cores
  3. Contain neuroendocrine markers (e.g., chromogranin, synaptophysin)
  4. Typically 100-200 nm in diameter
  • Their presence indicates neuroendocrine differentiation and is a key diagnostic feature of SCLC and other lung neuroendocrine tumors.

A. Small cell carcinoma has a strong relationship to smoking.

B. Small cell carcinoma is positive for CD 56.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER: 779.

questions.text:
Histopathological examination of a patient with hematuria reveals:

What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Shown picture is of Crescent shaped mass of proliferating epithelial cells and leukocytes within the bowman capsule.
  • It is characteristic feature of Rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis. (RPGN)

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER: 910.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child presents with massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia and edema with Normal blood pressure, Normal kidney function Renal biopsy reveals:

1. Normal glomeruli on light microscopy
2. No immune deposits on immunofluorescence
3. Podocyte foot process effacement on electron microscopy

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation with massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia and edema which are symptoms of Nephrotic syndrome and normal kidney function is consistent with minimal change disease.

  • The renal biopsy findings of normal glomeruli on light microscopy, no immune deposits on immunofluorescence, and podocyte foot process effacement on electron microscopy are characteristic of minimal change disease.

Option B: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults and not in children.

  • In light microscopy, there is focal and segmental lesions in glomeruli.

Option C: Membranous nephropathy (MN) is a kidney disease characterized by the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to immune complex deposition.


Option D: IgA nephropathy (IgAN), also known as Berger's disease, is a kidney disease characterized by the deposition of IgA antibodies in the glomeruli.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER: 914.

choices.text: ADPKD is caused by mutations in the PKD1 or PKD2 gene
PKD1 mutations account for 85-90% of ADPKD cases
Genetic testing can confirm diagnosis and identify carriers

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the genetics of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is FALSE?
questions.solution:
• ADPKD is also known as adult polycystic kidney disease. Its symptoms typically appear in adulthood.

Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of numerous cysts in the kidneys, leading to progressive kidney enlargement, impaired renal function, and, in severe cases, end-stage renal disease (ESRD).


ADPKD is caused by mutations in one of two genes: PKD1 (located on chromosome 16) or PKD2 (on chromosome 4). Mutations in PKD1 account for 85% of cases, while PKD2 mutations are responsible for the remaining 15%.

  • PKD1: Associated with more severe disease and earlier onset of symptoms.
  • PKD2: Leads to a milder disease course, with later onset of kidney failure.

The proteins encoded by these genes, polycystin-1 and polycystin-2, are involved in regulating tubular and cellular growth, fluid secretion, and calcium signaling in the kidney. Mutations lead to abnormal cellular proliferation and fluid secretion, resulting in cyst formation.

Option A: ADPKD is indeed caused by mutations in the PKD1 or PKD2 gene.

Option B: PKD1 mutations account for 85-90% of ADPKD cases

Option D: Genetic testing can confirm diagnosis and identify carriers.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER: 941.

choices.text: Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (RCC) associated with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome
Clear cell RCC with familial predisposition
Papillary RCC with familial adenomatous polyposis
Renal oncocytoma with familial renal cancer

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents with Multiple bilateral renal masses on imaging studies, Family history of renal cancer and pneumothorax, Skin lesions consistent with fibrofolliculomas.

Histopathological examination of the renal masses reveals:
1. Tumor cells with pale, flocculent cytoplasm and prominent cell membranes
2. Cells are arranged in a solid, alveolar, and trabecular pattern
3. No clear cell or papillary features are seen

Immunohistochemistry shows:
1. Positive for CK7 and CD117
2. Negative for CD10 and RCC

Molecular genetic testing reveals- Germline mutation in the FLCN gene

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient's family history and skin lesions are consistent with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome.
  • Chromophobe RCC is a less aggressive type of renal carcinoma, often associated with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome.
  • The histopathological features and immunohistochemical profile are characteristic of chromophobe RCC.

Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma showing the characteristic perinuclear clearing and distinctive (plant-like) cellular borders.

  • The germline mutation in the FLCN(folliculin) gene confirms the diagnosis of Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER: 949.

questions.text: What is the most common location for malakoplakia, the condition characterized by Michaelis-Gutmann bodies?
questions.solution:
• Malakoplakia is most commonly seen in the bladder.
  • It can also occur in other organs, such as the kidney (A), but the bladder is the most common site.
  • Lung (C) and endometrium (D) are less common sites for malakoplakia.

Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are a type of inclusion body typically in the context of malakoplakia, a rare inflammatory condition.

Characteristics:

  1. Calcified structures: Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are composed of calcium and iron deposits.
  2. Round or oval shape: They have a distinctive round or oval shape.
  3. Variable size: They can range from 5-100 μm in diameter.
  4. Presence in macrophages: They are typically found within macrophages.

Formation:

  1. Abnormal immune response: Malakoplakia is thought to result from an abnormal immune response to infection.
  2. Mineralization: The bodies form through a process of mineralization, where calcium and iron deposits accumulate.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER: 956.

questions.text: Which of the following occupational exposures is associated with an increased risk of bladder carcinoma?
questions.solution:
B. Aromatic amines, such as those used in the dye and rubber industries, are associated with an increased risk of bladder carcinoma.

Option A. Benzene is associated with leukemia, not bladder carcinoma.

Option C. PAHs are associated with skin and lung cancer, not bladder carcinoma.

Option D. Asbestos is associated with mesothelioma and lung cancer, not bladder carcinoma.


REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER: 958.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with IPF undergoes lung biopsy, showing Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern, Honeycomb fibrosis, Fibroblast foci. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of:

  1. Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern: Characterized by heterogeneous appearance with alternating areas of normal lung, interstitial inflammation, fibrosis, and honeycomb changes.
  2. Honeycomb fibrosis: Refers to the presence of clustered cystic spaces, typically in the subpleural regions.
  3. Fibroblast foci: Active areas of fibrosis with proliferating fibroblasts.

Is diagnostic of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF).

Option B: Nonspecific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP): Typically shows uniform inflammation and fibrosis without honeycomb changes.

Option C. Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP): Characterized by organizing pneumonia with or without fibrosis, but lacks honeycomb changes.

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Typically shows non-caseating granulomas without honeycomb fibrosis.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER: 689.

questions.text: 40-year-old female non-smoker presents with adenocarcinoma of the lung. Which of the following genetic alterations is most likely?
questions.solution:
• Adenocarcinoma is the most common subtype of lung cancer, especially in non-smokers.

A. EGFR (Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor) mutation:

  • EGFR mutations are common in adenocarcinoma (20-40%)

More frequent in:

  • Non-smokers (15-20%)
  • Females (10-15%)
  • East Asian population (30-50%)
  • EGFR mutations lead to constitutive activation of downstream signaling pathways, promoting tumor growth.
  • EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) are effective treatments for patients with EGFR mutations.

Option A. KRAS mutation:

  • More common in smokers (20-40%).
  • Less frequent in adenocarcinoma (10-20%).

Option C. ALK rearrangement:

  • Rare in adenocarcinoma (2-5%).
  • More common in young patients and non-smokers.

Option D. ROS1 rearrangement:

  • Rare in adenocarcinoma (1-2%).
  • More common in young patients and non-smokers.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER: 717.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male presents with hematuria and bladder mass. Histopathological examination reveals:

1. Invasive tumor with squamous differentiation
2. High-grade cytological atypia
3. Keratin pearl formation

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A. Squamous cell carcinoma (SqCC) of the urinary bladder is a rare but aggressive tumor.

Characteristic features:

  • Squamous differentiation: Tumor cells show squamous morphology, with:
  • Keratinization (keratin pearl formation)
  • Desmosomes (intercellular bridges)
  • High-grade cytological atypia:
  • Pleomorphic nuclei
  • Increased mitotic activity
  • Invasive growth pattern:
  • Tumor invades detrusor muscle or deeper tissues

Immunohistochemistry:

  • SqCC: Positive for cytokeratin 5/6, p63, and high-molecular-weight cytokeratin
  • Urothelial carcinoma: Positive for cytokeratin 7, GATA3, and uroplakin II

Option B. Urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation:

  • Urothelial carcinoma with focal squamous differentiation (<50% of tumor)

Option C. Adenocarcinoma:

  • Glandular or tubular architecture
  • Mucin production

Option D. Small cell carcinoma:

  • Small, round, blue cells with neuroendocrine differentiation

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER: 960.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with abdominal mass. Histopathological examination shows Oncocytic cells with granular cytoplasm, Nested architecture, and no cytological atypia. This tumor of the kidney typically arises from:
questions.solution:
Oncocytoma is a benign renal tumor characterized by:

  • Oncocytic cells with granular cytoplasm
  • Nested or tubular architecture
  • No cytological atypia

Oncocytoma arises from the collecting ducts, specifically from the:

  • Cortical collecting ducts
  • Medullary collecting ducts
  • The cell of origin is thought to be the intercalated cell, a type of collecting duct cell.
  • Intercalated cells have oncocytic features (granular cytoplasm).
  • Play a role in acid-base balance and electrolyte transport.

In contrast, other renal tumors arise from different parts of the nephron:

  • Clear cell RCC: Proximal convoluted tubules
  • Papillary RCC: Proximal convoluted tubules
  • Chromophobe RCC: Distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER: 948.

choices.text: Sclerosis involving the entirely of individual glomeruli

questions.text: Which of the following defines Global Glomerulosclerosis (GGS)?
questions.solution:
B. Global Glomerulosclerosis (GGS) is a type of glomerular injury characterized by:

  • Sclerosis (scarring) involving the entirely of individual glomeruli
  • Obliteration of capillary lumina
  • Collapse of glomerular tuft

GGS is often seen in:

  • Advanced chronic kidney disease
  • Diabetic nephropathy
  • Hypertensive nephrosclerosis
  • Chronic glomerulonephritis

Key features:

  • Global involvement of the glomerulus
  • Sclerosis and fibrosis
  • Loss of capillary lumina

A. Segmental Glomerulosclerosis: Sclerosis involves <50% of glomerulus.

C. Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): Sclerosis involves <50% of glomeruli and <50% of glomerulus.

D. Diffuse Glomerulosclerosis: Widespread sclerosis involves >90% of glomeruli.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN pathologic basics of disease, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NUMBER: 901.
